title: October 29
description:
France's Toussaint school vacation runs from October 24 to November 3.

Since the actual day of Toussaint is a Catholic holiday celebrating all the saints, known and unknown, we decided to visit the ancestral homeland of Catholicism: Italy! In the spirit of this Fall's labor strikes, we even returned the kids to school a day late to take advantage of cheaper airfares.

We spent a few days romancing the canals of Venice, then drove through the vinyards of Tuscany for a day, and from there drove to Rome for five days of exploring the ancient empire and epicenter of Catholicism.

Felix amazed us by keeping to a strict diet of lasagna. Lunch and dinner. Every day. However, soon after we arrived in Rome the lasagna-meter reached "full" and it was the end. We may, in fact, have broken Felix for lasagna for life.

This update covers Venice and Tuscany. We say ciao to Rome in next week's update.

children.title: Delivery Boat
children.description: Venice mornings are ruled by delivery boats.  They figure if they do it early enough, the tourists won't find out how the Coke gets to the restaurants.

children.title: Grand Canal
children.description:
When we arrived, we thought there'd be at least a few roads through the town. Nope. It's all canal all the time.

This is the Grand Canal, which curves in a S, dividing Venice in two.

children.title: Palazzo Odoni
children.description: Our hotel was in a former palazzo.   Très chic.

children.title: Traghetto
children.description:
To cross the Grand Canal, you either walk to a bridge (which could be pretty far), or take a special boat called a traghetto.

A traghetto's like a gondola except:

  • It just crosses the Grand Canal, instead of taking you on a tour of the canal system
  • There's TWO oarsmen (front and back, instead of just back)
  • It takes up to 14 people (if there's more than 4 or so, everyone has to stand)
  • It's 180 times less expensive (0.50€ instead of around 90€)

children.title: Gondola
children.description: THIS is a gondola.  It's fancier than a traghetto:  fur seats, gold trim, and you meet such fascinating co-riders (namely, your own family).

children.title: Gondola 2
children.description: Felix and Milo had a good time counting all the different types of boats there were:  delivery boats, police boats, ambulance boats, taxi boats, bus boats and even garbage boats.  LOTS of garbage boats.

children.title: Gondola 3
children.description:
Milo would like you to know he's very proud of his new Puffle hat. (Puffles are a creature from Club Penguin, a social network website run by Disney).

Yes, there's a Disney store in Venice.

The Puffle hat was on sale for dirt cheap. We don't think Club Penguin is catching on in Italy.

children.title: Gondola 4
children.description: Felix took this!

children.title: St. Mark's
children.description:
As luck would have it, another of the Ecole Bilingue families spending the year in Paris ALSO visited Venice and in Rome for the Toussaint vacation.

We caught up with Madeleine, Oliver and their parents in St. Mark's square and fattened the pigeons until a policewoman chased us off (but not the pigeons).

children.title: Madeleine
children.description: Madeleine, Felix and Milo cruise Riva degli Schiavoni.

children.title: Leonardo Da Vinci
children.description:
The church of San Barnaba had an awesome exhibition of model machines made from Leonardo Da Vinci's sketches.

Many of them you could actually operate. Definitely Dean and Felix's favorite spot in Venice.

children.title: Machine Gun Cannon
children.description:
Felix checks out Leonardo's machine-gun cannon system, which sadly was never built for real.

The Renaissance at its coolest!

children.title: From On High
children.description: The entrance to the Grand Canal, as viewed from the tower of San Giorgo church.

children.title: Gelato
children.description:
Dean read somewhere that it was reasonable to allow kids four gelatos a day when visiting Italy.

Milo in particular tried to hold us to that ambitious number, but the real average was somewhere between two and three.

children.title: Back Seat
children.description:
We rented a car in Venice and drove to Tuscany (and then on to Rome the next day).

It wasn't a long trip, but in the few short months we've spent without driving, Milo lost the car habit.

Unlike the stereotypes, Dean found Italian drivers to be completely sane. Rome traffic was a bit of a challenge, but rational as long as you ignored all lane markings, street signs and considered sidewalks a third lane for motorcycles.

children.title: Tuscan Runner
children.description: Milo is set free under a Tuscan sun.

children.title: Lucie
children.description: We stayed at an "agriturismo":  a working farm that rents rooms.

children.title: Pig Whisperer
children.description: Dean has this pig-snorting sound that ACTUALLY CALLS PIGS.   No one else can do it.

children.title: Foosball
children.description: Screw the pastoral scenery, the liquid sunshine, the divine food: Felix and Milo's idea of la dolce vita is unrestricted access to a foosball table.

children.title: Sunset Over San Leo
children.description: Sunset over agriturismo San Leo.

children.title: Olive Harvest
children.description:
It was olive harvest at the farm. All day, burly workers strapped big machines to the olive trees that shook free all the olives.

Lucie tried an olive straight from the tree but it was rinse-out-your-mouth nasty. The secret's definitely in the preparation.

children.title: Burnt Siena
children.description:
Siena is considered the prettiest medieval town in Italy.

For Dean and Lucie, it was a pilgrimage to the town that bequeathed Crayola the "burnt sienna" color.
